description: From Old French guiterne, ultimately from Latin cithara. Doublet of cittern.

entries.meaning: A small, quill-plucked, gut-strung musical instrument, most commonly with three to four strings in doubles courses; it is a flat-backed predecessor of the guitar, and it originated around the 13th century, coming to Europe via Moorish Spain.

verbs.description: gittern (third-person singular simple present gitterns, present participle gitterning, simple past and past participle gitterned)

examples: [...] [E]ach evening every one with mistress, or Ganymede, glitterning along the streets, or solacing on the banks of Jordan, or down the stream.
